COVID-19 District Update
Cases in Potter County Increasing
August 29, 2020

We are keeping a close eye on the rising cases in Potter County. In a little over a week we have gone from just a couple of cases to a total of 11 cases, with 8 of those 11 current active cases. Seven of the eight active cases have come in the last three days.

Since these cases are not known to be in the town of Hoven and because at this time we have no active cases in our school, we will stay at LEVEL 1-GREEN for now as we compare the numbers within our school community. In addition, the SDDOE also has our spread level as MINIMAL, which aligns with our plan to stay in GREEN.

Considerations may be given to a move to YELLOW if necessary. A school board meeting will take place on September 8, so we will wait and see what the next week brings and determine if we may need to move to YELLOW shortly after the Labor Day Weekend.

We will continue to monitor this situation daily and will keep you posted if anything changes.

Thank You.

Jeremy Hurd
Superintendent
Hoven School District 53-2

Peg Bohnenkamp Williams‚ÄéSouth Dakota History of Cities, Towns, places and people who made it great!
June 17 at 2:46 PM ¬∑

Peter Hoven, for whom the town of Hoven, SD, is named.

Another of Potter County‚Äôs Civil War veterans ‚Äì Peter Hoven, b. 1805 in Germany and d. 1890 at Hoven, SD. Peter and his wife Katherina were farming near Odell, Ill. when he joined the service as a 2nd Lt. with Company H, 2nd Wis. Cav. in Oct. 1863. He served in 4 battles before he mustered out in July of 1864 as a 1st Lt.

In May of 1883, Peter Hoven, Sr. and his son Peter Hoven, Jr., brought their families to the open prairies of Hoven township, Dakota Territory, where they lived in a cave for a year until a house could be built.

Peter, Sr., gave land, a bell, and a great deal of money to build a Catholic Church for the settlers in the area. His generosity prompted the new town to be named Hoven after him.

Peter, Jr. set up Hoven‚Äôs first bank, first hotel, a pool hall, a butcher shop, and an implement shop.

Monte Schatz‚ÄéSouth Dakota History of Cities, Towns, places and people who made it great!
April 23 at 12:41 AM ¬∑

Holy Infant Hospital in Hoven, SD was built in 1943 and was a 45 bed facility. This structure has personal meaning for me as I was born in this hospital in 1959.

Sadly, the hospital was forced to close in 2010 due to the inability to sustain itself financially. In a odd twist of fate, a few years after the hospital closed, the Hoven High School building was consumed in a fire.

The closed hospital served as the the temporary high school during the construction of the new high school. The first picture of the collage was the hospital building when it served as a temporary high school.

Since the new school was built the hospital building remained abandoned. My research did not indicate whether the building has fallen to the wrecking ball. Hoven was trying to find a new use, but indications were the old hospital was going to be demolished.
